abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Higher Education
            Development Project in Indonesia are as follows: overall
            outcome of the project was rated satisfactory, and the
            performance of the Bank and the Borrower were also rated
            satisfactory. Lessons learned: 1) project investments are
            likely to have large and sustained developmental effects,
            while the operation's positive outcomes and the
            problems encountered guided the Bank's future strategy
            in higher education; and 2) little consideration was given
            during project preparation to how investments were to be
            utilized and sustained. The project implementation unit was
            effective in implementing project inputs but had no mandate
            to assess utilization and impact of project investments. It
            would have been more efficient if: (a) the project had been
            financially integrated relying at least in part, on existing
            sources of finance at the university level, sources that
            would still be there after the end of the project; (b)
            planning of the project has been based on specific
            objectives as spelled out by the universities themselves;
            and (c) the universities not only had the responsibility of
            implementing the project but were also responsible for
            efficiently deploying the investments and routinely
            reporting on utilization and impact.
